critique: This executive order implements the Chemical Weapons Convention. It establishes the Department of State as the US National Authority, coordinates implementation with an interagency group, and authorizes various departments to issue regulations and carry out functions related to the convention. It also amends a previous executive order to restrict the importation of chemicals. The order prioritizes national security and law enforcement, particularly regarding potential violations. There is a moderate expansion of executive power to implement the treaty. The order does not directly address immigration, economic regulation, or social inclusion. It centralizes authority at the federal level to implement the treaty.
